In this video, the power rule was described as being a weird trick. The power rule is more than just a weird trick, it is provable mathematical truth. the proof relies on the "limit definition of derivative" which is the limit as h (just a variable) approaches 0 of ( ( (f(x+h) - f(x) ) )/h) ) now that junk there basically means you are finding the slope of the secant line that passes through an ever decreasing interval, which gives you the slope of the tangent line. with our function x^n, the lim. def. der. gives us "lim as h->0  ( ( (x+h)^n - x^n ) )/h) ) ". okay taking a step back for a moment we see that we need to fully expand the binomial (x+h)^n. as n increases the expansion of (x+h)^n has coefficients that follow pascals triangle, so the first two and last two in the expansion will be x^n + nx^(n-1)h ... nh^(n-1) + h^n. in our lim def der of x^n "lim as h->0  ( ( (x+h)^n - x^n ) )/h) ) " we now have "lim as h->0  ( ( x^n + nx^(n-1)h ... nh^(n-1) + h^n - x^n ) )/h) ) " which looks terrible but simplifies to "lim as h->0  ( ( nx^(n-1)h ... nh^(n-1) + h^n ) )/h) ) " and now we can factor out an h from the numerator and simplify with the h in the denominator and we get "lim as h->0  ( nx^(n-1) ... nh^(n-2) + h^(n-1)) )". now from here we just plug in 0 for h and we get that the derivative of x^n = nx^(n-1). you can find a much clearer proof somewhere else, but this is the best I could do with the Youtube comments

The problem is that mathematics doesn't work like the other topics addressed by Crash Course. Mathematics isn't simply memorization and remembering specific names, it is complicated logic-based processes that require hours of practice and deep thought to understand and apply further. Throwing pure equations at the audience doesn't have the same effect as talking about Plato or Abraham Lincoln. For the vast majority of people, looking at sequences of numbers and operations with no intuition or deeper context isn't going to do much at all.   Trying to squeeze an entire bloody branch of Calculus into a ten minute video is really tactless honestly and will do absolutely nothing for average people. I'd think the people at Crash Course would know this.

One way to define them:  Take a right triangle, i.e. a triangle with one right angle. Label the long side opposite from the right angle C, and label the other sides A and B.  Terrible ASCII diagram:         |  \  A   |    \       C        |      \                 |_ _ _\           B  Let's look at the angle between lines B and C (in the bottom right of my horrendous diagram).  Call this angle 'Q' (or whatever you like really).  We define the quantity sin(Q) (read: sine of Q) as the ratio of the line opposite to Q to the hypotenuse of the triangle, i.e. sin(Q) = A/C.  We define the quantity cos(Q) (cosine of Q) as the ratio of the line adjacent to Q to the hypotenuse: cos(Q) = B/C.  That's all sin and cos mean; they are defined simply as these ratios.    We often talk about the sine and cosine of an angle (call it P) that is not explicitly drawn as part of a right triangle. When doing this, we can imagine drawing a right triangle like the one above containing the angle P.  Note that since the sum of the angles in a triangle must equal 180 degrees, and since two of the angles are specified (the angle in question, P, and the right angle which is 90 degrees), we know what the third angle must be by subtracting P and 90 degrees from 180.  Since we are only concerned with finding the ratios of the sides of these angles, it doesn't matter what the actual lengths of the sides of the triangles are, so we can draw our triangle so that the side adjacent to P has whatever length we like.  Then using the geometry of triangles, we can figure out what the lengths of the other sides must be. We can then finally take the appropriate ratios to find the sine and cosine of P.  This is in principle how one might calculate the sine or cosine of an arbitrary angle, but it is very tedious so we would normally just ask a calculator to figure it out for us, or in the days before calculators consult a lengthy table of trigonometric values.

Saying that the derivative of e^x is e^x is deceptively simplifying the math.  The derivative of e^(2x) is 2*e^(2x), and the derivative of e^(x^2) is 2*x*e^(x^2); you have to use the chain rule.  This is a fact I had to learn on my own while studying for actuarial exams because (to my great frustration) every professor I've ever had insisted on parroting the fact that the derivative of e^x is just e^x.

Ok, I may make some mistakes but I will try to help. Derivatives are a type of Limit. Derivatives helps solving two main problems. (1) Finding the tangent line to a curve. (2) Finding the velocity of an object.  {The tangent line to a curve y = f(x) at the point P(a, f(a)) (<- that means a point in a graph,  where a is the value in the x-axis and f(a) the value in the y-axis) is the line through P with SLOPE m:  m = Lim ( x -> a ) of [ f(x) – f(a) ] / [ x – a ] That is read as ‘m’ equals the ‘limit’ of ‘f(x)’ minus ‘f(a)’, all of that divided by ‘x’ minus ‘a’, as ‘x’ approaches ‘a’.} {EXEMPLE: The slope of the tangent line to y = x² at the point P (1, 1)  a = 1  f(x) = x² m = Lim (x->1) of [ f(x) – f(1) ] / [ x – 1] m = Lim (x->1) of [ x² - 1² ] / [ x – 1] m = Lim (x->1) of [ (x – 1) * (x + 1) ] / [x – 1]   Note: (x – 1) * (x + 1) =  x² - 1 m = Lim (x->1) of [x + 1]                                  Note: (x-1)/(x-1) = 1 m = 1 + 1          Note: put the “a” value in the “x”, so that a = x. m = 2   Note: this is the slope of the tangent line that intersects with f(x) = x² only at the                        point P (1, 1).  Extra: To find the tangent line: y – y1 = m * ( x – x1 ) where y1 is the y value of the point P, and x1 is the x value of the point P. So y – 1 = 2 * ( x – 1) y = 2 * ( x – 1 ) + 1 Note: Isolate y. y = 2x – 2 + 1 y = 2x – 1  Note: This is the tangent line that intersects x² at P (1, 1).}    Derivatives: The derivative of the function f at a number a, f ’(a), is Let h = x – a f ‘ (x) = Lim ( h -> 0 ) of [ f( a + h ) – f(a) ] / h  Note: f’(x), means “f prime of x”. Alternate form: f ‘ (x) = Lim ( x -> a ) of [ f(x) – f(a) ] / [ x – a ] Alternate formula to find the Tangent line: y – f(a) = f’(a) * (x – a)  Derivative as rate of change: ∆x = x2 – x1  ∆y = y2 – y1     Note: just defined some variables, ∆ is ‘delta’. The instantaneous rate of change is Lim (∆x -> 0) of  ∆y / ∆x = [y2 – y1] / [ x2 – x1]  The derivative f’(a) is the instantaneous rate of change of y = f(x) with respect to x when x = a.  So as you see, it may take some time to calculate a derivative, so as the lady said, mathematicians found patterns and created shortcuts to make it faster. The more used rule would be the Power Rule.   There are two notations for derivatives: δx / δy   Leibnitz’s Notation. δ is a delta, small. f’(x)  Newton’s Notation. Reads, f prime of x.    Velocity is the derivative of Position.   V = P’ Acceleration is the derivative of Velocity.  A = V’  Sorry if I confused you even more. But it’s not something that one will learn in one try.

If you're meaning, why" e^x dx = e^x" is because just like f(x), the "e" is also a function like "f", rather than being treated as a number. As such, e^x actually is "exp(x)" just like "f(x)". This again is because of what e is equal to. That 2.7...number is actually a function of all integers. For example: Σ[n=0 & n→∞; where n ∈ R] (1/(n!)) = e. πί + ln(1) = 0 = exp(πί) + 1: so that exp(πί) = -1. As such, e is therefore treated as a function, even though it is equal to 2.7...and as such; n(x) dx = n(x) • 1 = n(x); where 'n' = e.  This is the derivative of a function: where 'x dx = 1' ∴ exp(x) = exp(x).

Now, you may think that because e = 2.718... that it must be worked as a number constant, well no.  e is the resultant of a function of all natural positive integers as the denominator of 1 as a factorial; along with many other functions involving specific numbers. This is also proven on a graph where y=exp(x) so that the gradient 'm=1 when x=1'.  Σ[n=0 & n→∞; n ∈ R] (1/(n!)) exp(πί) + 1 = 0 e = lim[n→∞] (1+(1/n))^n  This means 'e' is treated as a function and is equal to a set value at the same time.

Think of a derivative of the rate of how something changes.  Like for instance, let's look at speed. When I change my speed once, and immediately, then there was no derivative, because my speed had changed, but the time hadn't. It happened so quickly that my speed had changed but at that very instant My speed went from 0 to 100 in 0 seconds, basically, so 100/0 = 0, and if it was plotted on a graph, it would be a line that changes its gradient at some point immediately.  But if my speed changed periodically, in other words if I was accelerating, my speeds would have changed from 0 to 4, then 4 to 9, then 9 to 63, then 63 to 100, if I plotted that on a graph, it would be a curve, so doing distance/time to get the speed would be only an approximation, that gets more accurate and accurate as I make the changes smaller. Problem is, it's too much work that doesn't even lead to the real answer  This is where the derivative comes in, as it basically sums up all those small changes and allows me to find the EXACT speed at a certain time. For example, by doing that laborious work, my answers would be like 8.00000000000000043 m/s, but with the derivative, I can get the EXACT speed and have 8 m/s.  I know it seems like there's no point of all that, but it's very helpful in situations where physicists are trying to work with really small changes in space, or bullets or whatever it may be.  I hope this helped you  (EDIT: Think of the derivative AS the rate of how something changes)

The d just stands for difference. More specifically, it stands for the smallest possible interval (or change) in the thing it is next to. It's just notation used to show that you're differentiating. That's what she was saying at 4:00
dx/dt is the small change in X, divided by the small change in t. That is, the small change in position divided by the small change in time. That is, the velocity

Calling it small change is misleading. It is the change at that exact instant.  If you look at it in terms of speed, the dx/dt is the speed at an exact given T second, meaning at that exact instant. Before derivatives, the most we could do when it comes to trying to calculate an exact speed was calculating the average speed between two points.

Okay, the derivative of the sine thing was annoying me enough that instead of just griping, I decided to come up with a better explanation.  So let's go back to the Newton quotient (explained at 4:05 in the video):  (sin(t + Δt) - sin t)/Δt  Now, a bit of trig will tell you that sin(t + Δt) = sin t * cos Δt + sin Δt * cos t (an easy-to-understand geometric proof of this identity can be found at https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:AngleAdditionDiagramSine.svg ).  So the above becomes  (sin t * cos Δt + sin Δt * cos t - sin t)/Δt = sin t * ((cos Δt - 1)/Δt) + cos t * (sin Δt/Δt)  Now, one way of looking at trig functions - in fact, the oldest way - is to think about the chords of twice the angle.  If you draw a radius through the midpoint of such a chord, and two more to each end, what you'll get is two congruent right triangles whose hypotenuses are the radius and one of whose angles is that in question.  If we define our units so that the radius is 1, the length of the chord becomes twice the sine, and the length of the radius drawn to the midpoint becomes the cosine, with the length to the arc along that radius becoming one minus the cosine.  Now, as has been known since ancient times, as the angle gets very small, the length of the chord will be very close to the length of the arc (if you're not convinced of this, connect the endpoints of the chord along tangent lines and consider that the ratio of the chord to the sum of these segments is the cosine of the original angle, which approaches one), which, since we've defined the radius to be 1, is by definition equal to the angle in radians (hence the term "radian").  The distance between the midpoints of the chord and the arc, meanwhile, will drop much more quickly than the length of the arc for essentially the same reason (if you're not convinced, consider that it's the height of the triangle formed by the aforementioned segments, and that its relationship to the chord is therefore half the tangent, which approaches zero).  In short, sin Δt/Δt goes to 1, and (cos Δt - 1)/Δt goes to 0, so the above formula becomes simply cos t.  To get the rest of the way, just use the identities cos t = sin (t + pi/2) and sin t = -cos (t + pi/2), which follow very quickly from the definition.  And what the hell, let's go on to the exponential function.  Now, I'm guessing most of you were vaguely aware before starting this video that there was a constant called e, so to strip away the baggage, let's forget we know the answer in advance and call it b.  Use the Newton quotient again:  (b^(t + Δt) - b^t)Δt = b^t*(b^Δt - 1)/Δt.  Now, we can pull b^t right out of the limit, so that leaves that other term, (b^Δt - 1)/Δt.  So let's write the equation...  z = (b^Δt - 1)/Δt ∴ b = (z*Δt + 1)^(1/Δt)  Now, if z = 1, then the limit of the formula on the right, as Δt approaches zero, is one definition of e.  Since the actual value is just a matter of number crunching, I'm not going to bother to show what it is, only that it exists, so consider - let's consider only the values of Δt less than some value c, and you'll see they're bounded below by (z*c + 1)^(1/c) and above by (z*c+1)^(1/c+1), and the ratio between these two approaches 1.  Weirdly, even though it feels like it should be the most basic, I can't find a way to prove the power rule other than for integers that doesn't rely on half a semester of tricks.  So I'll just say for counting numbers it's basically just a matter of number-crunching ((t+Δt)^k - t^k)/Δt, and for negative integers it's slightly harder but basically the same idea.

Yes! That's the second derivative and in her example, it's the equivalent of going from a displacement equation to velocity to acceleration.

+Ryan B  Yes, that would be the second derivative.  She didn't really go into it here, but if you had some position function like s(t) = t^3 - 4t^2. Then the derivative would be v(t) = s'(t) = 3t^2 - 8t. Doing the same thing to velocity would be a(t) = v'(t) = s''(t) = 6t - 8. You can take one more meaningful derivative of acceleration, which is the jerk function j(t) = a'(t) = v''(t) = s'''(t) = 6.

Seeing these stuff from a perspective of someone who is only getting introduced to Calculus is rather fun. :D  I am an undergraduate electrical engineering student, so I've had my fair share of Calculus so far. (still having, and will...forever, damn it...) But coming to such a video was kinda... well.. cool, xD.  Electrical engineering is one of those engineering fields that is known to have more math than most of other engineering disciplines. In my university, electrical engineering department is the only engineering department that has Calculus IV in its curriculum (I'll be damned if I ever know why mechanical engineering students don't have to take it!) (differential equations is a course of its own, for all).  Still, however, I find the "dry" Calculus rather abstract. It makes so much more sense when it is applied to more tangible stuff. And most of my math doctors/professors really lack that skill, relating math to more concrete substance. Differential equations started making sense only after taking circuits. Laplace started making sense only after Signals and Communication courses, (though still trying to wrap my head around it in the Control Theory), and so did the entire concept of orthogonal dimensions and their usefulness. The whole thing with the complex numbers... it is way easier to see them in the phasor realm, simply as value with angles or rotation, than in the Cartesian-style, terms of i's (j's in electrical engineering) as an extra...sign? Eh... Even in terms of j, it really makes more sense when the imaginary part denotes for example the magnitude of reactive power or the rotation of signal's phase, than merely an abstract (-1)^(1/2) = j  Mathematicians still like complicating things... And almost never are able to... well... make people SEE the thing... they tell, and don't show... :/  As a final note: God Bless Khan Academy! The Savior of My Ass! :D

They give up too soon because it's scary(frustration, self-loathing and apathy sets in). 2. So if I were you, I'd go back to whatever level of math that does not frighten you, and you start from there. Luckily in this day and age there is so many helpful sites etc on the internet. There you can learning at a level where you are literally counting apples! No, I'm not joking:) We're talking kindergarten stuff, and all the way up to Multivariable Calculus and all that craziness. Hey guys! This video is great and extremely informative, however, they left out a portion of trig derivatives and e^x that will actually wind up giving you the wrong answer if you just do it the way they said to.  Let's say you have e^2x describing your position. If you do it the way CrashCourse said, your velocity would then be described as e^2x, however, this is incorrect. The correct velocity equation would be 2e^2x. This is because you have to multiply by the derivative of what e is being raised to when you take the derivative. This is similar with the trig functions. If your equation was sin(2x) your derivative would not be cos(2x), but would actually be 2cos(2x).  This was a simple mistake and something just looked over, but is very important in finding the correct equation using derivatives.

+CrashCourse x does not equal t^2. Rather, it is proportional to t^2. According to your last video, x=v0 t+(1/2) a t^2. Since v0=0, this simplifies to x=(1/2) a t^2. a is a constant term in this scenario; therefore, x is proportional to t^2. You can also confirm this by looking at the units of x and t^2 and seeing that they don't match up, so they can't be equal.

This series is going in the complete wrong direction.  If you are trying to do calculus based physics, then you are alienating a great deal of your potential audience.  I use Crash Course Chemistry and Astronomy in both Freshman and Senior level Physical Sciences.  They are scaled for use for different age groups and capabilities.  This series is beyond my basic Physical Science students (14-15 year olds), and has a greater mathematical focus than conceptual or algebra based physics courses.  In short, this series just jumped to a tier outside a huge portion of its potential audience.  Try to focus on conceptual ideas, and help students understand the math in terms of the relationships between values.

+aperson22222 Keep in mind, these functions mean totally different things.  If f(t) = 7t^6, then its derivative is f'(t) = 42t^5 (This gives you the rate of change of f(t) at any instant).  For example, f(t) might represent position, and then f'(t) gives you the instantaneous rate of change of position - velocity.  In the end, it's not a question of which one's better to deal with because they are both useful for different reasons.  Not to mention, in the grand scheme of things polynomial functions are relatively easy to analyze (compared to some other functions which can pop up).
